In India there is an enormous gap between healthcare supply and demand. What do you think are the major steps that can be taken by the government to improve patient care in the country?

As the saying  goes " Health is Wealth", the greatest wealth we can possess in our lives is good health. It's a boon to the mankind. It's our duty to protect this holy temple. This was a very philosophical view but the reality seems very different when it comes to healthcare especially in India. First and foremost owing to the large population, our healthcare industry doesn't seem too promising. There is a huge gap between the supply and demand. However, the gap seems to be increasing day by day even though government's primary focus is on healthcare. Where are we lacking? Is our government ineffective in implementing its policies on healthcare? or is it sheer corruption which is acting as a hindrance between the public and healthcare services?

Analysing the different reasons, we can say that the policies implemented by government do seem to work though partially. It is providing good emergency and timely services but not many people prefer it due to poor infrastructure. Majority of indians prefer private health services even though they are expensive, the reason being quality. Nobody wants to compromise on quality as lives are at stake. 

                                                 Affordability is another influencing factor. The prices of medicines are sky rocketing. The growth in healthcare and chemical sectors is slow owing to sluggish economy prevailing in India. Consumers have to choose between their lives and high prices. It seems very unfair but sadly, there is no choice left. This was from the customer's point of view but what about the chemical and healthcare industries? They cannot provide services at the cost of their mere existence. They are left to fend for themselves as a result of which the prices have gone up higher and higher.  Considering the  government's side of the story, it is smeared with corruption and corrupted officials. We keep reading about their scams every other day. The policies and strategies adopted by government have to pass through many officials, that is where they get delayed in reaching to the common man. In this whirlpool of problems relating to healthcare, common man is the worst sufferer. This is what is the poor state of affairs in the country.

But, there is HOPE. It requires tough measures, dedication and most important active participation by each one of us in the process of change. We, as citizens of India, have to choose the right government to lead us. Every one must use their judgement while voting rather than getting lured by the illegal money or false promises made at the time of elections. If the right government comes into power, there would be tremendous improvements in healthcare sector. They would ensure the right policies are implemented and the services are within the reach of the common man. Steps should be taken to curb the prices so as to make it affordable to everybody.

                                                          The chemical and healthcare sectors must be given more prominance and encouraged to attract more investments so that their cost of production falls down. The general public should be aware of the services being offered rather than falling prey to the fraudulent practices.Subsidies can be provided under strict supervision. Periodic auditing and inspection should be performed to ensure corruption free implementation of the policies.

                                 These measures will take time to become fully functional but the sooner, the better. The day is not far when India would flourish and prosper  tremendously in healthcare, where we can promise each and every child a better and a HEALTHY tommorrow.
